description: This is Rahb, the Observation Team Supervisor who will be assisting you in this office.
You recognize this person as the Deputy Minister of Health, a very important partner for you in this process.
This is the Finance Minister, who has been brought in today to explain the financial situation in Zariba as it relates to the health sector.

This is the Director of Regional Health Services for the Highlands region of Zariba. As you understand, this person works under the Deputy Minister and is probably the most knowledgeable person here when it comes to healthcare in the Highlands.

A woman who you imagine might come from the capitol stands before you. At first glance you notice she seems a bit disheveled and visibly annoyed. She is wearing a high-tech eyescreen headset and seems incredibly distracted.

A well-dressed middle-aged man leans against the ticket counter, casually reading the world news on his tablet. Next to him is a small cart filled with a dozen or so textbooks on the history of Zariba. You spy a university pin on the his lapel.

A young woman, maybe 19 years, is selling fruit from a well-stocked cart. Most of them you've never even seen before, and a perfume-like aroma wafts from a box of red berry clusters. She looks expectantly at you, smiling politely.

In the middle of the crowded marketplace, you see a man dressed in an impressive garb that feels important and professional, but at once authentic and grounded. He seems to be charming those around him as a small crowd gathers to listen to his sermon-like presentation. Behind him is an elaborate cart of small tokens and jars, all different sizes and shapes. The sign reads "Medicine" in multiple languages.

At the far end of the market there are two women in elaborate dress. You don't know where they are from, but they are certainly not from this region, nor do they look like they came from Capitol City. Very ornamental and expensive, their dresses pop and glide in different directions and both are wearing wild headpieces. You feel a sense of royalty from them.
A patient sits on a chair on the deck of the clinic, waiting for her turn to be seen.
A tired looking man with a stethoscope around his neck stands in the doorway of the clinic. He appears to be a doctor of some sort.
A well-dressed woman stands observing the plantation. She has evidently just come from the larger plantation house up the path.
A pair of older men sit under the shade of a palm, playing some sort of tile-laying game. The gaming set is finely crafted from polished wood, but seems old and well worn. They chat as they play.
A man leans up against a large piece of advanced farming equipment smoking a cigarette. It looks like he's taking a break.
A short man sits in the shade, tuning what looks like a harp. Haven't you seen him somewhere before?

A woman that looks to be in her thirties crouches down among rows of fresh crops, harvesting the land's bounty. Her movements are precise and efficient, like she has been doing this her whole life. She hums softly to herself as she works in rhythm with her motions. The only adornment on her otherwise spartan attire is a small, shabby locket dangling from her neck.

You see a man in his forties reading a news magazine in the shade, slight perspiration beading along his receding hairline. The magazine looks like one from the newsstand at the train station, perhaps dropped by a careless traveler some time ago.
A middle-aged woman walks down the path from the train station. She looks preoccupied by something, and perhaps a little angry. She carries medical texts with her, including a volume on midwifery.
A young man looking to be in his teens kicks a stone down the road. You notice a rolled-up flyer in his pocket that seems to be some sort of a "help wanted" notice.

A herder is wrangling a small flock of flightless birds toward the market, taking care that none wander off. You notice a medallion around his neck that looks familiar to you. Many people in this area seem to be wearing them.

An older man stands in front of a grand domicile. He grins broadly, gesturing emphatically as he speaks to a young woman who is clearly a customer of his. "Burn this incense before you sleep," you hear him say, "Every night for one month. No more and no less." The woman looks happy, and very grateful.

This man is clearly a merchant of some sort, with wares from all over Zariba. He calls out to people on the street, "Fresh fruit from Mile! Cigars from Crup! Technology from the Capitol! I have it all!"
A short man sits in the shade, tuning what looks like a harp. Haven't you seen him somewhere before?
An older woman stands with a young boy, probably her grandson. They seem a trifle lost.
A young man and woman, probably in their late teens, seem to be waiting to board an airship. They look very much alike. Probably they are brother and sister. Perhaps even twins.
A woman fidgets with her flight suit, tightening a loose strap and pulling her zipper a little higher. She appears to be in her late 20s, and preparing to depart soon via airship.
A man sits, tuning his harp. Haven't you seen him somewhere before?
A woman you recognize as the hospital administrator sits at her desk, going over some of the day's paperwork.
A woman sits in the waiting room, staring into space. Either she is waiting for her turn to see the doctor, or here with someone who is currently being examined.
Her assortment of luggage marks this woman as a traveller, and her clothes and attitude tell you she is foreign. Where could she be going?
A middle aged man is examining a medical chart of some kind. You recognize him as a doctor both by his attire and his nametag, "Dr. Notega."
The tall male nurse towers over everyone. Forehead scrunched in frustrated tension, he wipes a few beads of sweat from his brow.
A woman sits in the waiting room, staring into space. Either she is waiting for her turn to see the doctor, or here with someone who is currently being examined.
You recognize this person as the Deputy Minister of Health, a very important partner for you in this process.
You aren't sure what you were expecting for your coach but...no. This is it. Exactly. Right down to the baseball cap.
You heard Mr. Mokonanye used to be a police lieutenant and looking at him, you'd believe it.
The NGO Manager is a short man, and looks accustomed to worry. Or maybe his face is just like that.
Amina looks up from the stack of casefiles on her desk and smiles. You almost expect her to present you with fresh baked cookies.
The Clinic Manager is a big guy, with a big smile in his big beard. His smile lines compete with his frown lines, though.
You read 'Jaquilyn Appiah' on her nameplate, but when she shakes your hand she introduces herself as 'Jackie.'
The Supervisor seems all right angles: square shoulders and a sharp suit. Amicable, but not necessarily approachable.
You try to get the wiry man's attention, but even when he's talking to you his eyes dart away.
Your favorite traditional health practitioner.
Helps make your clinics special.

cities.description: Malcom is the line between more urbanized city environment and traditional farmland. The Train station runs between Mile and the Capitol, and there is a ferry that departs to Valeria once a day.

Home to the prolific traditional medicine provider (Mr. Todd), this is a bustling city that isn't as large as Zima or Malcom, but is still the center of trade and commerce for the smaller villages and towns in the central area of the region.

Valeria is one of the more affluent cities, and not part of the highlands region of Zariba. Unlike the rest of the country, the climate here is arid, and wealth and land are consolidated under entrenched “Land Barons.” More recently, it is the center of a growing commercial airship industry.
Accessed initially from the Capitol, Crup is a plantation-like farming village that has a deep divide between the high class owners and the workers on the plantations.

Positioned as a poor yet peaceful place in the mountainous southern region of the land, Mile shows many types of unique farm animals. People sustain themselves through farming the land, and value freedom and autonomy above all. Even though they are the poorest, there is a spiritual connection to their homes and the beauty of the location itself lends to a majority of content people.
Located on the sea, Zima is one of the largest and most industrialized cities in Zariba. Its most important landmark is National Hospital, the most extensive in the country.

This is the Capitol City of Zariba. Home to the offices of the Ministry of Health and where journey to help Zariba begins! The Capitol sits on the main transportation line. With easy access to the glorious rail system, travelers can go from the Capitol to the most southern city, Zima, in only a few days time.

grading.description: Congratulations on exceeding your goals. The pilot test we conducted has shown significant increases in all three major indicators. We are confident that over the next three years, this plan will continue to bear fruit.

The pilot test we ran showed some promising results. We have seen measurable increases in all three major indicators, especially in vaccinations. With proper implementation over the next three years, Facility Births and Quality of Care could rise to match it.

The results of our pilot test were mixed to say the least. Indicators have barely budged and are within the margins of error. We recommend re-evaluation of the context. A second attempt could yield a plan with greater efficacy.

We ran a pilot test and somehow, your plan as done more harm than good. Maybe RBF isn't the right answer after all. We strongly recommend re-evaluation of the context. More research and surveys should help. If this plan is put into practice, the implementer will have their work cut out for them!

There are just not enough initiatives put into place for this plan to move forward. Because of this, we weren't able to conduct an evaluation. I would recommend spending more time in the country in order to gather more information. Try visiting multiple cities and learning from many different people. You never know what you might learn.

text: Thank you again for coming all the way here. Your expertise is much appreciated. Our health system has been drastically underperforming despite our best efforts. Our mortality rates for children under five are unacceptable. We have identified three indicators to address to improve these numbers: Vaccinations, Facility Births, and Quality of Care. We have pushed facilities to improve on these indicators, but so far the results have been underwhelming. First and foremost, I recommend that you find a way to boost these key services and quality indicators.
unlocks_context: The Deputy Minister of Health says facilities are not providing enough of these services. If they are incentivised to provide more, they probably will.

text: The Finance Minister looks at you intently with a serious expression. "We have increased the budget for healthcare in each region year after year, but results have not increased to match it. This year, we will spend more than ever before. We need to try something new. That is why you are here."

Welcome again to Zariba! I hope you've had some time to yourself in the Capitol City to get your bearings, but of course, you are here to work. You'll be [[making a plan]] that will transform our health system over the next three years, but to figure out what should be in that plan, you will need to explore the country and [[talk to people]]

"You can use your notebook to keep track of where you have been, what you have learned, and what options seem to make sense for your plan. Click it now and explore it. As you can see, for now, it is mostly blank. That will change."

"In each area you visit, you will be able to talk to people just like you are talking to me, by clicking and spending options. You can only spend so much time in each city, though, so choose who you talk to wisely. I have taken the liberty of setting up a meeting with the Deputy Minister of Health, the Finance Minister, and the Regional Health Supervisor for the Highlands Region. It's starting now! Click on them to talk."
The Regional Director speaks up. "I have been trying to improve the health system in the Highlands region for a few years now, but there are [[many obstacles]]."

"The situation is not good, and we lag behind the rest of the country, and our neighbors," he says. "More than 80% of the people in the Highlands live in extreme poverty, and cannot purchase even basic health services. There is also some [[confusion]] about what to expect at health care facilities."
unlocks_context: The Regional Director of Health Services for the Highlands says 80% of people live in extreme poverty.

text: When you ask about the confusion, he nods. "Those with little money also have little time to educate themselves on matters of health," he says. "If we are going to be implementing radical changes, I'm honestly not sure how people in the rural communities of the highlands will be able to keep up."
unlocks_context: The Regional Director claims that it will be difficult to sensitize the populace on changes, so care must be taken.

text: The man extends a hand to shake and introduces himself. "Hello," he says, "I'm Dr. Maramuta. I run [[this clinic]], and I've consulted with a number of others in the area. Times are tough these days, and our [[budget]] has been seriously strained."
Dr. Maramuta motions you over to him. "I have to meet with a patient soon, but I have a little more time to chat. What else can I help you with?"

"Things have been very tough. In the highlands, things are done differently. The situation is not ideal, and sometimes the quick and dirty solution is better than no treatment at all. We have no money, and things are skimped on."
unlocks_context: Dr. Maramuta talked about cutting corners. This must be discouraged.

text: When you press him on budget strains, he backtracks a little bit. "It's not so much that we don't have any money, it's more that the budget has already been set by the Ministry of Health, and we don't have the ability to purchase the medicine and supplies we need. You understand."
unlocks_context: Dr. Maramuta in Crup needs autonomy to order supplies for his clinics.

text: You bring up Mr. Todd's claim that people travel long distances and receive no medicine. Dr. Maramuta nods. "This is sadly true, and also due to the budgeting issues I mentioned. It is a self-fulfilling prophecy. People tell their neighbors that there is no medicine, so people do not come here. Then since few people come, the Ministry adjusts our budget. Then when people do come, there is no medicine because of the budget lines we are given, and they spread the word. It will be hard to convince people that these problems have been solved."
unlocks_context: Dr. Maramuta says that clinics have a bad reputation. This needs to be countered.

text: He offers you a cigarette as you draw nearer, which you politely refuse. "Suit yourself," he says, taking another drag. He explains he has been working on the plantation for a few years now, and though the work is hard, the pay is reliable. "I just wish they paid us [[a bit more]]." [[Advanced Equipment]]
"You are still here?" the farmer asks. "Well then, what do you want to talk about?"

You ask about the expensive-looking machine he's leaning up against. "It's not mine," he says. "The Plantation owns this. They got a big grant from the government to modernize. Suits me fine, since I don't have to pick fruit out of thorns this way. We have a picture of the Prime Minister up in the cafeteria."
unlocks_context: A professor might have something to say about this.

text: You ask about the woman in Mile who takes pride in farming the land. "Pride is nice, but money is better. Even so, the pay does not go very far." He frowns, taking a puff from his cigarette. When you ask about affording health care, he laughs. "The clinic is fine, but I would rather save my money for something else, unless it's an emergency. You know?"
unlocks_context: Even workers on the plantation in Crup do not have enough money to afford services.

text:
You stand a little closer and are able to hear their conversation. "Damn arthritis," one says, grabbing at a tile.
The other replies, "You should visit Kibari and see Mr. Todd. Best medicine man in Zariba!" [[Keep listening]] [[Interrupt]]

"Excellent move," one says. 
"I have you on the run, now," replies the second. "Ouch... damn arthritis." 
"You need to see Mr. Todd."

You continue to listen in to their converation. "Mr. Todd, Mr. Todd. You always talk about him," the first man says, placing his piece on the board. "I might try it. The doctor at the clinic gave me some ointment and it did nothing. He told me to go to the hospital for some test, but that's all the way in Zima."
unlocks_context: It sounds like the wrong medicine was prescribed in Crup. Doctors must follow protocol.

text:
You interrupt their conversation to ask about Kibari. 
"People walk there. Mr. Todd's customers are very loyal. But if you do not wish to walk, a bus goes to Kibari twice a day..." the first man says. /n"It's your move," the other grumbles, growing impatient.
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Kibari.

text: The woman looks a bit exasperated, and not in the best health. When you ask her about her experience with the clinic, she offers a mostly [[negative account]]. "We are lucky to have a clinic nearby at all," she says. "But there are long waits here, and the clinic is very poor. I blame [[government incompetence]]."
She looks happy to see you again. Apparently she enjoyed sharing her experiences. "No one has ever asked me my opinions about something so important before."
"The rest would all be tolerable if the people at the hospitals and clinics were at least polite and helpful, but they are not. They treat us like a nuisance when they talk to us at all."
unlocks_context: Bad customer service discourages patients.

text: "The government can't get out of its own way," she says. "The governor claims they are increasing the budget for health care and doing many great things for people in the highlands, but where are the results? I do not see them. And it's not just this, it is everything they are involved with. They cannot be trusted to keep their word. I try to have no dealings with them."
unlocks_context: If the government is not a competent, reliable regulator, an NGO might fill this role instead.

text: She greets you in a business-like way and introduces herself. "Yes, I do own this plantation," she says. "Over a hundred people work and live here. It wasn't easy, but I have worked hard and built a legacy for my [[sons]] to inherit when I'm gone."
The plantation owner nods to you. "Was there something else?"
"I have two sons. They were both born right here, at home, [[the traditional way]]. I spared no expense and hired the best midwife in Zariba. It was a great experience."
unlocks_context: A midwife might have more to say about this. Find her.

text: "Yes," she nods. "In Zariba, it is customary that women give birth in their own homes with a traditional midwife in the room. I had a traditional midwife and a trained nurse in the room when I gave birth." When you ask about whether her employees can afford the same care, she shrugs. "I don't know what they do," she says. "It's not my business. Anyway they seem fine to me."
unlocks_context: The plantation owner says that women give birth in their own homes, even when this is dangerous.

text: You mention the entrepreneurial loan that Lydia told you about. The plantation owner nods. "We received one of those. This helped us purchase the land here. My husband also lobbied parliament to improve road access throughout the highland region and these upgrades are now underway."
I've never met you
You already finished one dialog tree
Go away

<address>"Things have been very tough. In the highlands, things are done differently. The situation is not ideal, and sometimes the quick and dirty solution is better than no treatment at all. We have very little money, and we find ourselves skimping and cutting corners in order to operate."</address>
unlocks_context: You unlocked a thing
You unlocked another thing

text: When you press him on what is being skimped on, he backpedals a little bit. "It's not so much that we don't have enough money, it is more that the budget has already been set by the Ministry of Health, and we don't have the ability to purchase the medicine and supplies we need. You understand."
unlocks_context: You unlocked a thing

unlockable_dialogue_clinician.display_name: Ask about why services aren't effective
text: When you press him on what is being skimped on, he backpedals a little bit. "It's not so much that we don't have enough money, it's more that the budget has already been set by the Ministry of Health, and we don't have the ability to purchase the medicine and supplies we need. You understand."
unlocks_context: You unlocked a thing

text: He pauses to speak with you, nervously keeping his birds in eyeshot, and occasionally redirecting them back to the flock. "Since you ask," he says, "I am a strong believer in traditional cures. They [[seem to work]], and they're [[easy to get]]."
"You are a curious one," the herder says.
"I heard that some people travel for days to get to the hospital, only to be told they have no medicine. Who wants to do that?"
unlocks_context: The herder mentioned people are discouraged to travel.

text: He clutches his medallion. "This is said to protect me from fevers, which kill many people in this area. I haven not gotten sick with a fever since I put it on. Hospitals on the other hand? Who even knows what happens in them?"
unlocks_context: People like the herder in Kibari believe strongly in traditional remedies that don't work.

text: A look of suspicion comes over his face for a moment, but it is quickly replaced with the same smile from before. "Greetings!" he says. "Yes, it is true. I am Mr. Todd." You recognize the name. "I would not claim to be the [[best medicine man]] in Zariba, but if that is what they say, that is [[what they say]]!" He gives you a knowing nod. "As for you, I know who you are. You're from the Ministry, here to promote your useless clinics."
Mr. Todd smirks at you as you return. "Still here, hmm? What more do you want me to say?"

He chuckles. "People come to me because I am already a part of their lives. Part of their community! The hospitals and clinics you want people to visit are not good. The nurses and doctors treat you like a stranger. No, like an interloper. An annoyance. They do not care about people like I do."
unlocks_context: If facility staff are not treating patients well, we should incentivise improving patient/provider relationships.

text: You press, and ask him what else people are saying. "People say lots of things," he replies. "For instance, those nasty rumors about what else has been going on in your hospitals. I heard some folks saying they believe hospitals are a trick to take our money, make us sicker, and degrade our whole way of life! I don't know how those get started. People say what they say," he reiterates.
unlocks_context: There seems to be some misinformation circulating about hospitals that dissuade people from using them. An information campaign could counter this.

text: "That's right! I say useless. Why would a person travel to see a doctor who can't even give them medicine? Ask your doctors that. Meanwhile, when you go to me, you leave with medicine in hand. Even better, my cures are distributed far and wide."
unlocks_context: Doctors are not providing medicine? Find out why at the clinic in Crup.

text: "Folks around here call me Nomad. Care to hear a song?" His light fingers pluck out a pleasant tune. When his song ends, he looks at you [[expectantly]].

You drop a few appreciative coins into his hat, and he thanks you. "And here's a tip for you. If you're interested in medicine, make your way to Zima for sure. But talk to Dr. Maramuta at the clinic in Crup before you leave Zariba. Most people in the highlands never see the inside of a hospital, but clinics are pretty common."

He extends a hand for you to shake as you come nearer. When you ask him what he thinks about hospitals, he seems mostly positive on them. "I would go to a hospital if something was wrong with me," he says. "But I'm healthy, thank goodness. A lot of other people seem to [[distrust]] the hospitals though, especially in [[this area]]."
The teen waves as you draw nearer. "I was wondering if I would see you again. Something else you want to talk about?"

"Well," he says, "It is simple enough. The medicine is foreign. The hospitals are far away, and when you get there, you are treated by strangers. It is just unfamiliar, and people distrust what is not familiar. Perhaps if these hospitals hired more people from this area, that would help. People might be more willing to go to them if they could count on seeing friendly faces. And besides, we could use the work around here."
unlocks_context: Hiring nurses from local areas could encourage people to visit facilities.

text: "You must know where you are. We are in the heart of the highlands. People here are used to doing things the old way. That means Mr. Todd." He points to the lavish domicile further along the road where a well-dressed man stands.
unlocks_context: People are well-ingrained in the old ways of doing things. You will have to work very hard to promote your own services.

text: When you approach him, his eyes light up. "What can I do for you?" he asks. "Anything you need, I have it." You buy some trifle from him out of politeness, and after that he seems happy to share what he knows about the area. "The nearest cities to here are [[Crup]] and [[Mile]]. Both easy enough to get to. I'm actually on my way to [[Zima]].
"Anything else you need?" he asks, watching as you approach.

You ask about Mile, and he offers some advice. "In Mile, no one has any money at all, but it is on the route to the capitol city, so I pass through from time to time. If you want to get there, just hop on one of the produce trucks that makes the rounds from here to there. They leave pretty frequently."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Mile.

Crup.text: "The people from Crup," he says, "Are poor, except for the plantation owners. They can only afford basic things. There is a clinic there, though. If you want to go there, there is a bus that departs in the mornings and evenings."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Crup.

text: "I'm headed there soon. Nice city. Port town. With a large hospital, too. You can tag along with me and I'll show you the way."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Zima.

text: He introduces himself enthusiastically and tells you about his work studying political science and the old Zariban empire. His friendly demeanor shifts into annoyance as he speaks about his need to get to [[Mile]] and rolls his eyes at the picture of the [[prime minister]] on the front page of his paper.
The professor closes the window on his tablet and looks you square in the eye. "Back to continue our conversation?"

You ask him about Mile: "I haven not been down that far south in decades but I hear the life hasn't changed much. Good people who still remember life before the the current regime took power." He indicates the Prime Minister's photo as he speaks. "You can take the train through Mile into Zima, though the tracks have been terrible for years."
unlocks_context: Find someone in Mile who has traveled. They can confirm this...

text: As soon as you say the words prime minister his eyes grow wide and he puts down his paper. "You know, ever since the new government took power, the train has gotten worse and worse. They should be investing in transport instead of inviting foreigners into the country to pillage our resources." He eyes you appraisingly before continuing. "I will tell you this, the government is corrupt and incompetent. They are not respected in the highlands, where they still remember the old regime. They can't keep the trains running, and they won't be in power for long."
unlocks_context: If the professor is right and the government is not a strong partner, an NGO might be needed to make sure services are delivered.

text: You bring up the farm bill you learned about in Crup. "You mean the massive bribe given to landowners out of the people's pocket? Just more proof that this government needs to buy support. It is like the papers say; the Prime Minister is far more interested in pleasing foreigners than helping his own people." You don not argue, but it strikes you that he is contradicting himself.

After a few attempts of getting her attention, she tells you how she has been waiting for hours for the next train out of the station. "There have been two trains heading to Mile that have already been [[cancelled]]!" Flustered, she mutters under her breath about being late to meet [[her friend]]."
She's finished with her phone call now, and it's easy to get her attention again.

She nods, looking unhappy. "Unfortunately, this happens all too often. The train has been the main way both people and goods move through the country for longer than I can remember. But it is unreliable."
unlocks_context: You learned from a traveller that most goods move by train, but the train is unreliable. A private company could avoid this problem.

text: You learn she is attempting to head to Zima, the southern city on the water, to visit her friend Doctor Notega at the hospital there. "We are very close, and since he has been frustrated with his job, I want to help him have a little fun for a few days. Apparently he has not been receiving supplies, or so he says. If you go there, ask him, and I am  sure he will tell you all about it."
unlocks_context: Doctor Notega in Zima will know more about this.

text: "Fresh fruit!" she calls as you approach. "Only the best, grown by local [[farmers]]. Try the berries! They are my [[daughter]]'s favorite." She hands you a sample. "No charge," she says.
The woman looks at you with recognition and offers a wave as you return. "Can I help you with something else?"

You ask about the farmers who grew the fruit. The woman replies in a rehearsed tone. "Very hardworking people. Very poor, but who needs money when you can eat what you grow? I live in the city, so I have to sell fruit to make ends meet and support my family."
unlocks_context: People like the fruit vendor can't afford services, so vouchers may be necessary.

text: "My daughter? She is just three, and the cutest girl you have ever seen," the fruit seller beams. "Her grandmother is watching her, so I can sell fruit here in the market. I support all three of us." When you ask about the girl's vaccinations, the woman shrugs. "Who has time to travel to a hospital? Keeping her fed is more important."
unlocks_context: The fruit seller in Malcom doesn't have time to travel. Bringing Outreach staff to her area could solve this.

text: "You are looking ill, my friend!" he says to you by way of greeting. "We have the cure for whatever ails you. All of our products are 100% derived from the land itself, and we never use any ingredients of foreign origin. Our medicine is the only cure that has been proven by centuries of practice here in Zariba. We are headquartered in [[Kibari]], so all our products are checked for authenticity by [[Mr. Todd]] himself!"
"Was there something else you needed?" the Merchant asks. "Whatever you need, I have it!"

You approach the man and ask about Kibari: "Kibari is the heart of the highlands, and the center of commerce and traditional knowledge for the nation. From Kibari, the whole nation is open wide to you. It is easy enough to get to. Just hitch a ride with one of the local farm transports. They come and go every day."
unlocks_context: You've discovered a new route to Kibari.

text: As soon as you mention Mr. Todd the medicine merchant's face lights up. "I might be a bit biased, but that man is everything for the local region. He is a genius who has built a business from the ground up! Literally! Everyone loves Mr. Todd. You need to meet him. I'm sure one conversation with him will change all your thoughts on foreign medicine!"
unlocks_context: Mr. Todd in Kibari will have more to say about this.

text:
As you approach they both turn to eye you up and down, and you feel a sense of being judged for your attire. They turn back to each other smirking, continuing their conversation. 
"This market was fun for an hour or so, but I just cannot wait to be back at the estate. Did you hear? Uncle will be renovating the outer sand gardens to make space for three new horses!"
 The second woman smiles. "That sounds lovely. Hopefully next spring he'll finally put in that airship tether he's always going on about." [[Keep Listening]] [[Interrupt Them]]
They're still talking, but they seem aware that you're nearby. You're beginning to feel a little awkward.
You've been noticed. "What time is it, dear? The ferry home should be here soon..." is all they say.
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Valeria.

text: They seem surprised that you're addressing them, and even more surprised that you'd be asking them about healthcare. "We're from Valeria," one of them says. "So I'm not sure what I could tell you about highland clinics." The other considers for a moment. "You know who would know? Lydia. The airship pilot. She's having a baby soon, I heard. If you pass through Valeria, you can ask her."
unlocks_context: Find Lydia in Valeria to ask her about this.

text: As you step closer, she stops what she is doing and looks at you askance. "Not that I am not thankful for an excuse to rest and talk," she says, "but I have a lot of work to do. This harvest will feed my [[family]], and others in the village." There is a hint of [[pride]] in her voice.
The farm worker hums to herself. When she sees you approach, she pauses. "Back again?"

"I have two sons and a daughter, a husband and a brother," she explains. When you ask about their health care, she shrugs, looking a little guilty. "I barely have time to do what needs doing here, you know? Between doing my work and taking care of basic needs, who has time to think about health care, let alone visit a hospital? Taking care of basics like food and water, and a roof that does not leak is far more important. Besides, some people are scared of the hospitals."
unlocks_context: People are more concerned with leaking roofs than vaccines. Offering a credit for a new roof at clinics could bring patients in.

text: "I guess I am proud of it," she smiles. "My family has farmed this land for generations. Soon my children will be old enough to contribute, and carry our family on to the next generation. This makes me very happy. It's not just about feeding ourselves. This isn't some plantation like Crup. We work for ourselves here. Money's just not that important to us."
unlocks_context: Ask a farm worker in Crup for another perspective on this.

text: When you give her the opportunity, she is all too happy to vent. She explains that she is a [[midwife]], and that she just had a job interview at the hospital in Zima. "Or at least I [[thought I did]]."
She looks frustrated and ready to continue venting. "I will tell you something else."

She is clearly still steamed about what happened at the hospital as she relates what happened there in angry tones. "I travelled more than a day to get there, and did the entire interview, only to be told there were no resources available to hire me! The hospital administrator said she would love to have me on their staff, but a new position was not budgeted."
unlocks_context: Ask the Hospital Administrator in Zima more about this.

text: She scoffs. "Skilled midwives such as myself who can travel are very hard to come by, and very in demand these days, since most women won't travel long distances to give birth. I can't believe they would not hire me."
unlocks_context: A budget for outreach staff is necessary, according to the midwife in Mile.

text: You ask the midwife about what the plantation owner said. "Yes, that is true. Women do prefer to give birth at home, and I don't see that changing any time soon. People don't like being told they are wrong. My advice is to focus on improving facilities and spreading the word, not attacking old customs."

He greets you with a friendly nod. "I've been just about everywhere in this country, you know? I travel here and there, play my harp, busk up a meal, and then on to the next place! The people here are poor. Can't give me much coin for my time, but that just means they need music the most. So I always stop in this town on my way to the next destination. What they lack in money they more than make up for in hospitality and spirit. Good cooks, too!"

You return to the train station and immediately it is clear that something is not right. People seem worried, or even angry, and they crowd around an information booth. It's chaotic here, but you manage to learn that bad weather has triggered landslide to the east, and the train tracks between Mile and Zima have been destroyed. They could take weeks to repair! A group of young men tug on your shirt and grin. They say they drive a produce truck that is leaving the city right now, and for a small price, they can get you to Kibari, the heart of the highlands. "From there," they say, "you can get anywhere!"

He does not seem particularly bothered by your presence, and rests the magazine on his lap to speak with you. After a few minutes of idle conversation, he volunteers a little more about his past. "I was not from here originally," he says. "I came here as a refugee many years ago, back during the old regime. It was a very [[difficult journey]]." A frown spreads across his face. "My village was destroyed by a [[landslide]] during a rain storm. It will never be rebuilt."
He looks up from his magazine to greet you. "Nice to see you again. Did you want to discuss something with me?"

"Some people miss the old regime," he says, "but they never did anything for me, you know? I have lived through a lot, and democracy seems much better than the alternative." He fans himself with the news magazine and finishes his thought. "Some people disagree, and wish they could go back. But most don't care. I would ignore the nationalist claptrap that some spout."

"It was so terrible," he says. "Unless you have seen one, it is hard to describe. The entire village was just gone. Many people died. I lost family members. I feel lucky that I was able to make it here, and was accepted and given hospitality, even though people here do not have much. They gave all they could and more."
unlocks_context: The refugee in Mile talked about landslides. An outside organization might be better equipped to cope with these.

text: He nods and explains how travel is very difficult unless you can afford to buy a train ticket. "And few can! If you can't afford a ticket, you must walk along the tracks, and it is very dangerous. Recently, someone died making the trip to Zima, and now no one even tries it unless they are desperate, you know?"
unlocks_context: It is difficult and dangerous to travel, according to the refugee in Mile. Bringing Outreach staff to villages may be necessary.

text: "Oh, hello," the woman says. "This airship port wasn't here the last time I came to this town, so it's a little confusing. We were visiting here for a little bit. My [[grandson]] always wanted to see the sand palaces."
"Oh, hello again. What else do you want to chat about?"

When you inquire about the health of her grandson, she seems a little unsure. "I think he's vaccinated," she says, "but I don't really care for these hospitals. When I went, the nurse was very rude to me. He made me feel unwelcomed, and I had to argue with a doctor about getting a [[prescription]] for my little one."
unlocks_context: The Grandmother in Valeria thinks the nurses are rude.

text: "I don't remember exactly what the doctor said, but he kept saying that he did not need antibiotics. When I finally got him to write me a prescription, I felt like he wrote it just to shut me up. He didn't seem to care, you know?"
unlocks_context: Doctors are writing prescriptions to please patients, not for solid medical reasons.

text: She seems very at ease as you approach, and introduces herself as Lydia, an airship pilot. "These airships are pretty new, so not many people can fly one. This one here is [[mine]]," she says with some pride, pointing to a floating craft. "I'm about to depart on a [[personal trip]] to [[Zima]], and I'm just going through my flight checklist."
"I am about to head out. Was there something else you wanted to talk about?"
You ask about Zima. "I do have room for a passenger if you are headed that way..."
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Zima.

text: You ask how she was able to afford the airship, and she tells you about an entrepreneurial loan she received from the government last year. "I could not have afforded it otherwise. They do a lot of good in this region. They have my vote."
unlocks_context: Are many people being helped by the government? Ask the plantation owner in Crup.

text: You mention the women in Malcom who referred you to her. Lydia rolls her eyes. "I hope they weren't too rude to you. They were right, though. I'm actually three months pregnant today," she offers, "and I have an appointment with Dr. Notega in Zima. If I'm being honest, I wouldn't trust any other facility for this. The clinics don't seem to have the resources."
unlocks_context: If clinics lack resources to deliver facility births, incentives for this service may be needed.

text: "Funny seeing you here," the harper says. "You can call me Nomad. Most folks do. I've been everywhere in this country. This part of Zariba is probably the richest. Land Barons have been building palaces out of sand for hundreds of years here. Not sure how they get the sand to hold together, but it seems to work. The airships are new, though. Got to change with the times."
The two are having a conversation about where they'd like to go this weekend, and whether to take an airship ride or not. [[Listen]] [[Interrupt]]
The twins are still chatting with each other. "I can't wait to get out of here. This airship dock isn't my idea of fun."

"I wish Lydia was flying to the capitol instead of Zima. Who cares about some boring hospital? The nightclub in that city is so over." 
 "Her airship is so tiny anyway. We barely fit," the other says.
unlocks_context: You discovered a new route to Zima.

text:
They stare at you for a moment when you approach, then ask who you are. When you explain yourself, they are happy to share their opinions on Zariba's health care system. "The highlands are where all the poor people live," the brother says. 
"He knows that," his sister interrupts. "Everyone knows that. We were both born here in Valeria, in our own house. No one likes to go to these hospitals. They're so run-down and uninviting." 
"I've been in one. They just feel dirty, and they smell. And the staff look like street people," the brother agrees. "That's why no one wants to go to them."
unlocks_context: The twins in Valeria say that people avoid the hospitals because they look run-down.

text: At first, he seems too engrossed in the chart to devote his full attention to you, but once you introduce yourself, he puts it down and apologizes. "I wish I had time for a formal sit down with you," he says, "but time is tight around here. I will try to share as much as I can. This hospital works very well for the rich, since they can afford whatever [[tests]] and procedures we order, but [[poor people]] tend to shy away from us, which is a shame."
Dr. Notega seems a little overwhelmed, but he pauses in his work to talk to you. "Anything else you want to know? I am happy to talk while I have a little time."

You ask more about the poor people of the highlands and he gives a frustrated shrug. "The majority of people in the highlands have no money. They can't afford basic preventative care. Even if they could, I'm not sure they would purchase it."
unlocks_context: Dr. Notega says only the rich can afford medicine.

text: "I admit, we perform a lot of expensive tests and certain other procedures for our few affluent customers. That is the only thing that keeps the lights on in this facility."
unlocks_context: At the hospital, services that 'keep the lights on' are prescribed. We could incentivise the services we need delivered.

text: You ask about the supply issues his friend told you about back in the train station. "Yes, there are serious supply issues, but the problem's not the train. It's our budget. The hospital administrator can tell you all about this, I'm sure."

You strike up a conversation with the traveler, and she explains that she is investigating the mining industry in [[West Zariba]] for her company. "It is a [[long journey]], and I dread the trip through the highlands."
"My car is leaving soon," she says. "So make it quick."

She looks anxious. "I will not be taking the train. Instead, I am taking a private motor car. I am afraid of trains. I leave in a few hours, bound for Kibari, which I hear is the center of the Zariban Highlands. I guess it is kind of exciting."
unlocks_context: You've discovered a new route to Kibari.

text: She's happy to tell you about West Zariba. "It is a long way from the highlands," she says. "Because of international interest in rare elements, this area has been invested in heavily by the Zariban Government. They are quite capable of building infrastructure when they are motivated to do so."

She notices you, and rises to shake your hand. "Very pleased to meet you. I have been expecting you, actually," she says. She begins a frank explanation of the hospital's challenges. "The worst thing has been a lack of supplies. We are frequently out of stock on basic things due to [[budget constraints]]. This has a [[trickle-down effect]] on many other hospital functions."
The hospital administrator looks frustrated. She tugs on her hair as she pores over some document. When she sees you again, she looks up. "Oh, I thought you had left. What else can I tell you?"

"The root cause of the constraints is simple bureaucracy. How we spend our budget is determined by a ministry bureaucrat in the capitol city who has no idea what our actual needs are. If we had the autonomy to allocate our budget nimbly, the supply issue would go away."
unlocks_context: The hospital administrator says she lacks the autonomy to purchase needed supplies.

text: "When we do not have the proper supplies, it looks bad to the patients, and we lose face. Not only that, the lack of basic supplies begins to wear on my staff. I am aware of some attitude problems. All of this is not conducive to treating people."
unlocks_context: Stressed staff have 'attitude problems' according to the hospital administrator.

unlockable_dialogue_hospital_administrat.display_name: Ask about the midwife in Mile
text: You bring up the midwife you met in Mile, and the administrator nods. "Same problem. We did not have the autonomy needed to budget for that hire, so I had to turn away a qualified, needed worker."
unlocks_context: In Zima's hospital, midwives are needed but they lack the autonomy to hire them.

text: Once you get him talking, the nurse seems almost relieved to have someone to complain to. "I work harder than anyone in this facility, but compared the doctors, I get paid practically nothing! I deal with [[angry people]] every day. He just writes [[prescriptions]]."
The nurse motions for you to come back over to him. "Listen to me, and I will tell you how things really are," he says.

The tall nurse crosses his arms. "They get angry when I tell them they must go to the drugstore. They don't understand anything. They think the hospital is a pharmacy. They ask stupid questions. I get tired of it. You've never heard of a drugstore? And then when the pharmacy does not have the drugs… That is my fault TOO?"
unlocks_context: Nurses are clearly over-stressed, and provide poor service.

text: "Yeah, patients aren't happy unless they leave with a prescription in hand. Lucky for the doctors, they can just write them. Then it's me who has to try and fill it. I've seen antibiotics prescribed for viruses, or even for nothing at all, just because it's the only medicine we always have in stock."
unlocks_affects: According to the nurse, doctors are prescribing medicine for the wrong reasons.

text:
She seems surprised when you sit down to talk with her. She explains that it cost her [[a lot of money]] to get here, but it was necessary since her headaches do not go away.
"I have more money [[than most]]," she continues, "so I should be thankful, I suppose. I got vaccinations for my son, and the doctor said he is too skinny, so they gave me some protein bars."
"Still waiting!" she says as you approach. "Did you want to talk about something else?"
"Would you believe it? The train cost me more than the medicine!"
unlocks_context: A patient in Zima complained it is expensive to travel.

text: "Most of my neighbors cannot afford even simple health services like vaccinations or doctors appointments."
unlocks_context: Most people cannot afford services, according to a patient.

path_config.prompt_year_1: Thank you for joining us for the end of year meeting. It seems like your plan implementation is going smoothly, yes? That said, we would like to know if you need anything approved through us to make the plan run more efficiently. It seems like your plan is runnign quite well, but there is always opportunity for slight modification.
path_config.prompt_year_2: You've made it to the end of year two. I hope you are checking your indicators and making sure the RBF plan is running smoothly. Is there anything you need from us? If the new Clinic Manager is not working out we can make internal adjustments.

choices.text: Suggest replacing Mr. Todd with another Clinic Manager

problems.name: Government Overreach on Verification
problems.initiating_dialogue: The ministry has asked us to send copies of all our reports to them for verification. I thought that was supposed to stop that and send only to the third party verifier? I guess I'm still a little confused.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: We are very interested in making sure the providers are doing what they say, and we have the staff available to review, so why not?

feedback.clarify_separation_of_functions_1: all right, i understand. I'll inform the staff here.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I know the Minister of Health fairly well, and I can tell you that things go more smoothly if you're cooperative.

coach.dialogue: Duplicating efforts seems to be hampering the health providers. I'd either clarify everyone's roles for them, or empower health providers to push back somehow.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: I didn't know about this. If the Ministry is doubling our verification efforts, it could prove very confusing to the providers.

community_verifier.dialogue: As long as these things get verified, that's all that matters to me.

clinic_manager.dialogue: Honestly, we've been ignoring the ministry's requests. We've got too much actual work to worry about.

feedback.authorize_providers_to_take_action_at_th: OK I'll bring it up the next time they send in their request, however, I will need some technical support to convince the ministry decision makers.

problems.name: Bad Record Keeping
problems.initiating_dialogue: The Clinic submitted their reports to us, but there were some inconsistencies. When we asked to see their records, they could not supply them.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: If they are not following the rules, they should not be paid. A penalty may also be in order.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: All providers in my region should know the requirements for keeping records. Something must be wrong. I'd talk to them.

coach.dialogue: I don't know why they aren't keeping records. When I spoke with them last, they said everything was fine and they didn't want my help.

feedback.help_build_capacity_1: I will strengthen on the spot training during the verification for them to see the mistakes they are making.

community_verifier.dialogue: My team has had no issue keeping records. I wonder what the issue is at the clinics?

clinic_manager.dialogue: The reports we submitted are correct, I can give you my word on that. The problem is we do not have the time and resources needed to keep and collect all the records required.

feedback.hold_payment_1: We will improve things next quarter.
feedback.sanctions_1: We can hardly pay staff as it is! Many patients will go untreated because of this.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Perhaps they just need some more time to get used to all of this. This is all new. Cut them some slack this once, and they'll figure it out as we go.

problems.name: Poor Management
problems.initiating_dialogue: The clinic submitted their reports to us, but there were some inconsistencies. When we asked to see their records, they could not supply them.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: There are other health providers in the region we could use. This is the largest, but it doesn't mean it is the best.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: The staff at the hospital have been slow to adapt new practices.

feedback.terminate_contract_effective_end_of_year: It seems early to terminate their contract, but let's review at year's end. In the meantime, I will be observing and offering ways to improve.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: The data we've been seeing from this provider does indicate fund mismanagement.

community_verifier.dialogue: I would talk directly to them if I were you.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I don't really have time to talk about this right now. Sorry.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: We're doing our best here.  There are many intricacies to the business plan, and not everyone on my staff understands them. I'm sure they'll get used to it soon, though.

feedback.warning_and_retraining_1: Do you really think this is necessary?

problems.name: Dodging Responsibility
problems.initiating_dialogue: I requested a meeting with the Clinic Manager recently to go over their record-keeping practices, but it keeps getting rescheduled and canceled. I can't get a firm commitment from them. It is a little suspicious, frankly.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: There are other health providers in the region we could use. It seems this one is becoming more difficult to work with. It might be worth discussing their contract with the purchasing agency.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I have experienced similar problems with this provider. It is hard to schedule their time. More regular meeting times might help.

feedback.terminate_contract_effective_end_of_year: That's pretty drastic. Let's discuss this at the end of the year. I'll make it clear to them they are on notice.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: That does sound suspicious. I'll be looking carefully at their records this quarter.

community_verifier.dialogue: I would talk directly to them if I were you.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I think you underestimate just how busy we have been with outreach and patient care. We are not a large staff, and our time is very precious. Maybe next month things will be slower.

feedback.warning_1: I'm sure I'll have some time next quarter once our busiest time dies down.
feedback.revise_business_plan_to_include_regular_: That will be extremely dicey. We are tight on time as it is. I'll see what I can do, though.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I've observed the clinics we're talking about a number of times, and there's never enough time and money to go around.

problems.name: Mismanagement
problems.initiating_dialogue: I was visiting the hospital for my mentoring visit, and they are still mismanaging funds. The business plan has clear guidelines the Administrator is not sticking to.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: I have been slammed with meetings all week, and don't really have time to discuss this right now. Sorry.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: Have you considered that there is a flaw in the business plan? If the Hospital Administrator is straying from it so often, it might need to be reevaluated.

feedback.revise_business_plan_1: I will schedule a meeting this week with the purchasing agency and begin the revision process for next quarter.
feedback.sanctions_and_retraining_on_use_of_finan: I'll make some time this week for a retraining session and try to drill down on exactly how these tools should be used. I'm informing the regulator about the sanctions now.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: If i had to guess, I would say this is simple mismanagement, nothing fraudulent.

community_verifier.dialogue: I'm not really sure. I haven't even been to this hospital!

clinic_manager.dialogue: When was the last time you revised the business plan?

hospital_administrator.dialogue: We need to spend money where it's needed, and as the administrator of this hospital, I know where it is needed. That was the purpose of granting us autonomy in the first place.

feedback.warning_2: I will do my best, but I I'm really worried things are going to start breaking down soon.

problems.name: Lack of Transparency
problems.initiating_dialogue: There is an ongoing issue with the Clinic Manager. They are small things, but since they have been having issues with record keeping, I looked more closely and found some forms that seem like exact duplicates of others.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: This is very distressing. I urge you to deal with this harshly.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: This is troubling to hear. I may begin looking into other providers for you to contract next year.

coach.dialogue: This is a big deal. If these records are not accurate, we have no way of measuring progress. We need to send a very clear message. Unvalidated reports cannot be paid.

feedback.warning_3: I'll warn them. Hopefully we will see some improvement next quarter.

community_verifier.dialogue: That sounds pretty suspicious.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I told my staff to start keeping better records. I can talk to them again and stress its importance...

feedback.mild_sanctions: Our budget has been wearing thin as it is! I will have to fire staff because of this.
feedback.strong_sanctions: This is a disaster! For such a small error? I will have to fire staff because of this, and will not be able to order needed supplies.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Don't go too hard on them. These clinics do good work.

problems.name: Inconsistent Indicators
problems.initiating_dialogue: We are seeing some indicators rise while others stay stagnant. Hospital births are barely rising, though checkups and vaccination rates are improving. We need to see all indicators rising!

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I suggest hiring more outreach staff to operate in facilities near these settlements.

feedback.hire_more_outreach_staff: This makes a good deal of sense to me.

coach.dialogue: We've tried many strategies to improve stagnant indicators. Perhaps the indicators need to be reviewed at the end of the year?

feedback.review_indicators_at_end_of_year: It might make sense to revise goals down, or at the very least, perform another survey to make sure our population estimates were correct.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Are you concerned about fraud? I haven't seen direct evidence of it.

community_verifier.dialogue: People here are still reluctant to travel to facilities.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I admit, we haven't seen as many facility births as we'd like. We're doing everything we can to change that.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Vaccinations are easier to manage. Births take more planning. More resources are likely required to make this work.

feedback.raise_incentives_for_facility_births: That will make this a good deal easier for us.

problems.name: More Transparency
problems.initiating_dialogue: I was visiting one of the clinics in the network for my mentoring visit, and I was unhappy with their transparency. There were some records I was told were unavailable, and I was not able to meet with the staff as I wished.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: I was under the impression that the plan required transparency.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: This has gone far enough. We should order a total audit of all their practices.

feedback.terminate_contract_at_end_of_year_3: I will warn them that their contract is in danger of being terminated at the end of the year.
feedback.capacity_building: I feel like I've been doing this for a year already, but let's see if we can't make some progress

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Their record keeping has been spotty as well, though it has improved since last year.

community_verifier.dialogue: I would talk to the provider directly on this matter.

clinic_manager.dialogue: We are simply over worked here, and have little time for meetings when our patients are sick and already have long waits. The Coach should be helping us build capacity, not draining our capacity.

feedback.audit: Very well, I'll clear some time. I'd be interested to hear your suggestions on improving things.
feedback.warning_4: I'll try to make my staff more available next time.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I haven't been having this problem, so I'm not sure what to tell you.

problems.name: Wrong Numbers
problems.initiating_dialogue: I have been reviewing the Hospital Administrator's records, and they do not check out. There is either fraud or accidental misreporting here.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: If needed, I could suspend their license to practice, but I don't think it will come to that.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I've had some communication issues with the Hospital Administrator in the past, but I believe he is honest. You should talk to him directly to see what the problem is.

coach.dialogue: This is the first time we've seen this behavior from the Hospital Administrator. I'd recommend a warning.

community_verifier.dialogue: The sample I surveyed does not align with the numbers you say they reported. Very suspicious.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I don't think the hospital should get preferential treatment over my clinics. Treat them just as you would treat us.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I think my staff is confused about what to report. Frankly, I myself have been confused at times!

feedback.hold_meeting_to_retrain_on_reporting_pra: I think that will probably help. Let me know when works for you and I'll clear some time.
feedback.warning_5: I'll talk to my staff and try to settle this.
feedback.sanctions_3: I just put in orders for new equipment. Now I won't be able to afford to pay for them. I think you are talking this too far. It was an honest mistake.

problems.name: Budget Lines
problems.initiating_dialogue: I received a memo today going over the new national health budget. The ministry has released new hiring guidelines for all providers, but it does not match our goals.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: Our own monitors have found mismanagement of funds. They need strict guidelines to provide the necessary services.

feedback.clarify_separation_of_functions: This is within the scope of regulation, which is my role. But if you think it's essential, we will step back on this.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: If the Ministry is claiming this is necessary, I would take it seriously. A compromise might be to re-work the business plan with Ministry oversight.

coach.dialogue: I have found some mismanagement of funds in the past as well. However, we are supposed to be granting autonomy.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: I have noticed some inconsistencies in the data that indicate to me some funds are being mismanaged.

community_verifier.dialogue: I don't understand the need for these new guidelines, but then again, I am not working in the hospital.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I need to be able to hire whoever is needed. This is a return to the status quo that I do not agree with.

feedback.revise_business_plan: I don't believe this will be constructive, but I'm willing to try.
feedback.sanctions: I just put in orders for new equipment. Now I won't be able to afford to pay for them. I think you are talking this too far. It was an honest mistake.

problems.name: Failed Inspection
problems.initiating_dialogue: Hey, we just received a memo telling us we failed a quality of care inspection, but I disagree with the assessment. Given the amount of strain we are under, I believe we need to be granted some leeway in order to serve patients.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: Quality of care is important insofar as it enables better and more services to be deleivered.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I recognize that their job is difficult, but quality of care is one of the indicators we are working to improve.

coach.dialogue: Quality of care is not something we should grant leeway on. It is crucially important to the plan!

third_party_verifier.dialogue: They failed inspection, plain and simple. A review is not necessary.

community_verifier.dialogue: These are small clinics, with very little operating budget. Denying payment will cause immediate harm to the community.

Feedback.review_the_inspection: Thank you! I think you'll find our quality is sufficient.
Feedback.warning_6: I don't know what we can do to improve things before the year is out.
Feedback.deny_review: This may be a serious problem. I was not paid last quarter, and it looks like I won't be paid this quarter.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I can tell you it is painful to miss a payment, even when things are going well. What harm is there in reviewing the inspection?

problems.name: Over Capacity
problems.initiating_dialogue: We've seen some great improvements over the past three years, but now the hospital is butting up against capacity. We might need to expand hiring to keep up with demand.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: This is great news, as far as we're concerned!

feedback.expand_hiring_of_hospital_staff: Perfect. This should ease our capacity problems.

coach.dialogue: From what I've seen, some extra help would go a long way, but I am concerned about the learning curve for new workers.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: This is a good problem to have.

community_verifier.dialogue: The people in my most recent sample have been happy with the services they received, but did report long waits.

clinic_manager.dialogue: I'd love to have more staff. Or is this just for the hospital?  Don't forget to take care of the people doing the hard work at the clinics.

feedback.expand_hiring_at_all_facilities: This was needed very badly. I look forward to meeting my new recruits.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I am worried about on-boarding many new people. Perhaps we should reward the people who have got us this far? Bonuses and overtime would make my staff happy.

feedback.award_bonuses_to_hospital_staff: This will really help motivate my staff. Thanks!

problems.name: Checkup Overload
problems.initiating_dialogue: We have been looking at the numbers, and outpatient consultations have risen much faster than projected. We can't explain it.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: For some reason people in this region have been taking advantage of this service much more than others. Perhaps providers are pushing the services too strongly.

coach.dialogue: We can reduce the fee for this, but we need to think carefully about what other effects that will have on the plan.

feedback.decrease_incentives: I'll research the best way to do this without having any undesired effects.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: They all seem to be legitimate, so I don't suspect fraud. Would you like me to go over the paperwork again?

community_verifier.dialogue: We have heard rumors of people going to the hospital and being offered services they don't want.

clinic_manager.dialogue: What's wrong with people getting outpatient services? It's better than the alternative.

feedback.maintain_current_rates: Smooth sailing ahead. Nice talking to you!

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Really? I haven't noticed that at my hospital. Anyway, I thought treating people was a good thing.

feedback.warn_providers_to_follow_protocols: I'll have my staff re-assess these practices.

twists.name: Mismanagement
twists.initiating_dialogue: I was visiting the hospital of Provider 2 for my quarterly audit, and they are still mismanaging funds. The business plan has clear guidelines they are not sticking to.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: Sorry, I'm kind of up to my elbows in work here, I don't know if I have much advice to contribute to this situation.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: Have you considered that there is a flaw in the business plan? If Provider 2 is straying from it so often, it might need to be reevaluated.

feedback.revise_business_plan_3: I will schedule a meeting this week and begin the revision process for next quarter.
feedback.retrain_1: I will make some time this week for a retraining session.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: I really don't think that this is in my wheelhouse; maybe somebody else on your team would have a better idea?

community_verifier.dialogue: Wow, uh, I'm not really sure what I would do in your shoes. That might be in somebody else's job description, though.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: The business plan is far too restrictive! You need to give us all more latitude in how we spend the funds you give us.

feedback.warning_8: I will do my best, but I don't see a sustainable path forward with the current plan.

twists.name: Reversal
twists.initiating_dialogue: Hello! Again, I must say I am very pleased to be working with you. My customers though, are less happy. They are reluctant to go to your hospitals even though I refer them. Couldn't you train someone here to do the work of your nurses?

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: I really don't think that this is in my wheelhouse; maybe somebody else on your team would have a better idea?

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I am not comfortable with procedures taking place by new workers and trainees unsupervised. I might approve stationing a nurse at traditional medicine facilities.

coach.dialogue: If they won't come to facilities, having trained people near them is better than nothing. Why not expand our travelling nurses program instead?

feedback.embed_nurses_1: An interesting idea. I'll help facilitate this as best I can.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Wow, uh, I'm not really sure what I would do in your shoes. That might be in somebody else's job description, though.

community_verifier.dialogue: People are reluctant but I believe they could be swayed to come to facilities. I recommend keeping the plan as it is.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Sorry, I'm kind of up to my elbows in work here. I don't know if I have much advice to contribute to this situation.

feedback.expand_travelling_nurses_1: It will take some time to do this, and there is a shortage of qualified people, but I will do my best.

feedback.train_locals_1: Excellent! I have a good feeling about you, friend.
feedback.stick_to_the_plan_1: I warn you, they will not accept it.

twists.name: Inconsistent Indicators
twists.initiating_dialogue: We are seeing some indicators rise while others stay stagnant. Hospital births are barely rising, though checkups and vaccination rates are improving. We need to see all indicators rising!

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: Hiring more traveling nurses to staff facilities near settlements is my suggestion.

feedback.expand_travelling_nurses_2: This makes a good deal of sense to me.

coach.dialogue: Perhaps the indicators need to be reviewed at the end of the year?

feedback.revise_indicators_at_end_of_year_3: It might make sense to revise these goals down.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Wow, uh, I'm not really sure what I would do in your shoes. That might be in somebody else's job description, though.

community_verifier.dialogue: People here are still reluctant to travel to facilities.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Vaccinations are easier to manage. Births take more planning. More resources are likely required to make this work.

feedback.incentivise_facility_births_1: That will make this a good deal easier for us.

health_provider_3.dialogue: You should accept more traditional techniques into your plan. People should have the choice, don't you think?

twists.name: Overflow
twists.initiating_dialogue: We have more referrals than expected from the traditional medicine practitioners. It looks like some people are going more than once.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: I'm not sure working with these people was the best idea. Maybe we should seek another partner for next year.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: We need to send a clear message that this is unacceptable. Strong sanctions are what I recommend.

coach.dialogue: A warning should be sufficient. This is their first year, after all. I can work more closely with them in the coming quarter.

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Sorry, I'm kind of up to my elbows in work here, I don't know if I have much advice to contribute to this situation.

community_verifier.dialogue: It sounds like Provider 3 is taking advantage. This is not going to build trust in the new system.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: Maybe I should stop honoring these referrals, or scrutinize them more carefully at my level?

feedback.increase_scrutiny_1: I will need some assistance to put these protocols in place.

health_provider_3.dialogue: I am only doing what you asked, and referring people to the hospitals. What is the problem?

feedback.warning_9: Many apologies! I think I now understand the problem.
feedback.sanctions_4: Why do I even refer people if you punish me afterwards? This is foolish.
feedback.terminate_contract_at_end_of_year_4: But we have only just begun! Pray, please reconsider.

twists.name: Wrong Numbers
twists.initiating_dialogue: I have been reviewing the Hospital Administrator's records, and they do not check out. There is either fraud or accidental misreporting here.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: Sorry, I'm kind of up to my elbows in work here, I don't know if I have much advice to contribute to this situation.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: I've had some communication with Provider 2 in the past, but I believe he is honest. You should talk to him directly to see what the problem is.

coach.dialogue: This is the first time we've seen this behavior from Provider 2. I'd recommend a warning.

community_verifier.dialogue: I can confirm the numbers do not match up. Very suspicious.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I think my staff is confused about what to report. Frankly, I myself have been confused at times!

feedback.warning_7: I'll talk to my staff and try to settle this.
feedback.sanctions_4: I just put in orders for new equipment. Now I won't be able to afford to pay for them. I think you are taking this too far. It was an honest mistake.
feedback.hold_meeting_to_retrain_on_reporting_pra: I think that will probably help. Let me know when works for you and I'll clear some time.

twists.name: Budget Lines
twists.initiating_dialogue: I received a memo today going over the new national health budget. The ministry has released new hiring guidelines for all providers, but it does not match our goals.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: Our own monitors have found mismanagement of funds. They need strict guidelines to provide the necessary services.

feedback.clarification_of_roles_9: This is within the scope of regulation, which is my role. But if you think it's essential, we will step back on this.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: If the Ministry is claiming this is necessary, I would take it seriously. A compromise might be to re-work the business plan with Ministry oversight.

coach.dialogue: I'd speak with the Ministry about this right away.

community_verifier.dialogue: I really don't think that this is in my wheelhouse; maybe somebody else on your team would have a better idea?

third_party_verifier.dialogue: I have found some mismanagement of funds in the past as well. However, we are supposed to be granting autonomy.

feedback.revise_business_plan_4: I don't believe this will be constructive, but I'm willing to try.

twists.name: Money Troubles
twists.initiating_dialogue: Hello! Wonderful to talk to you today. I have a problem, however. Some of the traditional healers I work with are telling me they do not wish to refer to your facilities. They say they could make more money by selling the traditional remedies that you are replacing.

dep_minister_of_health.dialogue: This sounds like extortion to me. If they aren't willing to fulfill the contract, I say let them go.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: This is just one of their negotiation tactics. Don't indulge them, and they will fall into place again.

coach.dialogue: Can we afford to pay them more?

third_party_verifier.dialogue: Sorry, I'm kind of up to my elbows in work here, I don't know if I have much advice to contribute to this situation.

community_verifier.dialogue: Wow, uh, I'm not really sure what I would do in your shoes. That might be in somebody else's job description, though.

hospital_administrator.dialogue: I would hate to lose their referrals. This program has been fairly successful.

feedback.increase_referral_incentives_1: Excellent! Everything will continue to run smoothly.
feedback.continue_with_plan_1: I warned you! Do not say I didn't warn you.
feedback.terminate_contract_at_end_of_year_5: What? This is very foolish. I hope you reconsider.

twists.name: Field Records
twists.initiating_dialogue: We are having difficulty tracking the effectiveness of travelling nurses in the field. We can't confirm they are meeting goals or having positive impacts on indicators.

feedback.increase_funding_for_verifiers_1: Really? I don't think we should be rewarding mismanagement.

director_regional_health_services.dialogue: It might help if they were clearing their movements through my office. Then we would know where they are going, and that they are headed where they're needed.

coach.dialogue: Our CBO partners should be confirming all of this. I don't think it's the nurses' fault. The verifiers need to know that if they can't adequately do the work, they can be replaced.

feedback.centralize_control_over_travelling_nurse: I'm wary of adding another level of bureaucracy to this, but it may help...

third_party_verifier.dialogue: The records filed by travelling nurses are sloppier and often late, since they are in the field instead of the hospital.

community_verifier.dialogue: We often do not hear that a nurse has been to visit a patient until after she is long gone, so it's difficult to verify everything.

feedback.warn_community_verifiers_1: We'll try to come up with a strategy to tackle this. It can't be insurmountable.

feedback.require_nurses_to_return_to_file_1: Many of my facilities are not much better than the field, and it will add to our own filing burden.
